1: This is a very complex area!  Oral and written evidence to Committees is published on the Committee's pages: e.g. http://www.parliament.uk/business/committees/committees-a-z/commons-select/home-affairs-committee/publications.  Command Papers are the collective name given to different types of papers prepared by the Government and presented to Parliament with the words "presented to Parliament by command of His/Her Majesty". The following documents are all types of Command Paper: Treaties, some White papers, some Green Papers, some Government replies to Select Committee reports, reports of Royal Commissions, reports of some major committees of inquiry, annual reports and statistics of certain bodies (judicial, penal, immigration).  These are published by Government rather than Parliament: https://www.gov.uk/government/publications and use "official document status" filter on LH side of page.  Also available for public inspection in Parliament.  For further info see http://www.parliament.uk/about/how/publications/government/

2: Hard copy publications are still produced, and there is a charge depending on length.  See: http://www.tsoshop.co.uk/parliament/bookstore.asp  However, online equivalents are always available free of charge at: http://www.parliament.uk/business/publications/

1) Lei de Acesso à Informação (Access to Information Federal Law) - nº 12.527 / 2011   The law implements the constitutional right of access to public information on the three levels of goverment.    (www.acessoainformacao.gov.br/assuntos/conheca-seu-direito/principais-aspectos/principais-aspectos )   2) Ato da Mesa (Governing Board Act) nº 45/2012  Provides for the application of the Access to Information Law within the Chamber of Deputies (http://www2.camara.leg.br/legin/int/atomes/2012/atodamesa-45-16-julho-2012-773823-normaatualizada-cd.html)

According to law, a report on the Knesset expenditures is submitted to a joined committee headed by the Knesset Speaker. The protocol of the committee is on the internet. See example from 2013 -   http://www.knesset.gov.il/protocols/data/rtf/knesset/2014-07-28.rtf
There is no procedure of submitting evidence to the committees. Reports of papers that are submitted before a meeting will usually be open to the public on the committee website.

2: The Knesset rules of procedure Ensure that the parliamentary information is open and accessible to the public. http://knesset.gov.il/rules/eng/contents.htm  http://main.knesset.gov.il/Activity/Pages/RulesOfProcedure.aspx Paragraph 38 of the rules and procedure of the parliament states that – "The minutes, as well as the detailed results of the electronic voting, shall be published on the Knesset website.". http://knesset.gov.il/rules/eng/ChapterC5.pdf   Paragraph 74 -  of the rules and procedure of the parliament states that Bills that have been laid on the Knesset table, shall be published on the Knesset website. http://knesset.gov.il/rules/eng/ChapterG1.pdf   Paragraph 118 of the rules and procedure of the parliament states that "the meetings of the Committees are public".  http://knesset.gov.il/rules/eng/ChapterH5.pdf  Paragraph 120 of the rules and procedure of the parliament states that – The all the protocols of the meetings of the Committees will be open to the public and will be published in the Knesset website according to this paragraph.

Rules on public access to proceedings in the Croatian parliament and its working bodies:  http://www.sabor.hr/Default.aspx?sec=734 these are key areas regulated by the Rules: - the presence of representatives of civic associations, non-governmental organizations and citizens as observer at the parliament session and sessions of working bodies,  - visits of organized groups of citizens to Parliament,  - way of recording sessions of Parliament and its bodies,  - direct radio and television broadcasts during the session,  -  way of registering domestic and foreign journalists in the Parliament  - website of the Parliament.
